page.title: 05Cliffe Common - Ecology
page.content: Cliffe Common was enclosed last century, and is now used for farming. One of the old roads on to the common is still there. It is nearly overgrown and called Broad Lane Wood. Cliffe Parish Council owns this land and has just had a report from the Nature Conservancy Council about it. The report says the land should be kept as woodland because it is a valuable habitat for wildlife. Oaks are the commonest{trees, there are some very large hawthorns also rowan, crab apple, holly and hazel.{Flowers}include primroses and cowslips, and wood buttercup which only grows in old woodland. {Roe deer}come to the wood from the larger wood on Skipwith Common to the north, and there are{grey {squirrels}and owls.
